ygData.subject: Re: Size of search-space (was: Bloat)
ygData.msgSnippet: Mike, I know of no efforts to try NEAT on a supercomputer.  It would definitely be interesting.  The same goes for trying NEAT with any massively parallel

Mike, I know of no efforts to try NEAT on a supercomputer.  It would 
definitely be interesting.  The same goes for trying NEAT with any 
massively parallel system.  Ultimately it just means more 
generations in less time, but it might make a difference in orders 
of magnitude, which could substantially change the natureo of what 
evolves.

I'm not sure to what your second question about solving "what sort 
of problems have been proposed" is referring?  Do you mean regarding 
implementing NEAT on a supercomputeror some other kinds of problems?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Michael Gillam" <gillam@m...> wrote:
> Kenneth,
> 
>     What sort of efforts are being pushed to try NEAT approaches on
> supercomputers?  And to solving what sort of problems have been 
proposed?
> 
> Thanks!
> 
> -Mike
> 
> ----- Original Message ----- 
> From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...>
> To: <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Tuesday, June 15, 2004 3:48 PM
> Subject: [neat] Re: Size of search-space (was: Bloat)
> 
> 
> > Ian,
> >
> > I am in complete agreement with the spirit of your point about 
modular
> > structures potentially reducing the effective space of search.  
I'd
> > like to formalize it a little bit further here...
> >
> > What we have to do is distinguish between the spaces of the 
genotype
> > and the phenotype, since they can be quite different in 
dimensionality
> > depending on the mapping between them.  Then, as long as we are 
clear
> > about which space we are talking about, there will be no 
ambiguity
> > about the meaning of a dimension.
> >
> > In general, all of my arguments about the need to evolve variable
> > length genomes are about *genotypic* space.  Of course, with 
NEAT in
> > its current form, this is a trivial statement, since the 
dimensions of
> > genotype and phenotype are the same.  However, in a future NEAT
> > wherein the genotype goes through an indirect mapping to 
phenotype,
> > the dimensions of the genotype may be much fewer than the 
phenotype.
> > Neverthelsss, all the arguments still apply: we still wish to 
minimize
> > the number of dimensions in the genome.  It's just that now they 
are
> > going to be mapped to somethin different in the phenotype.
> >
> > What this analysis suggests, and what I ultimately believe is
> > happening in this field, is that there are two parallel yet
> > complementary directions of research that should ultimately 
converge:
> > 1) The idea of complexification through starting minimally and
> > protection of innovation inside NEAT is a generic methodology for
> > evolving in any genotypic space, and 2) an (extremely) clever 
indirect
> > mapping would allow very compact representations.
> >
> > 1 with 2 means efficient search plus efficient representation.  
Thus
> > they go together very neatly.  You may think for a moment that 2
> > precludes 1, since perhaps if the mapping is sufficiently 
powerful the
> > number of dimensions necessary in the genome will be so low that 
1
> > will become irrelevant.  However, that is not likely to be the 
case.
> > Even in indirect mappings we are likely to need many hundreds or
> > thousands of genes, even though those genes may be reused.  Note 
human
> > DNA, with 30,000 genes.  These 30,000 genes are reused in such 
amazing
> > proportions that they somehow map to 100 trillion connections in 
the
> > human brain.  Yet even with this brilliant reduction, 30,000 is 
still
> > a lot of dimensions, and still is unlikely to be optimized 
through
> > direct search in the genotype space of 30,000 dimensions.
> >
> > Therefore, I believe the field should head towards NEAT-style
> > evolution of indiretly encoded genomes.  I don't know if you saw 
when
> > I mentioned our paper, "A Taxonomy for Artificial Embryogeny," 
but it
> > is a large review of this area that you may be interested in:
> >
> > http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:alife03
> >
> > I agree that modularity is a big deal in evolution, and it should
> > definitely be at the forefront of future researh.  However, 
sometimes
> > the way we think about modularity may be misleading since we are
> > tempted to think as engineers whereas evolution is not like an
> > engineer.  We have a short paper on this topic as well:
> >
> > http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:gecco04ws
> >
> > ken
> >
> >
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> > > Hi,
> > > (I've been on holiday so I'm a bit out of daye, this is from
> > Kenneth's
> > > long discussion of about a week ago)
> > >
> > > Great analysis!  Just one small additional thought:  what do we
> > mean by
> > > "dimensions" in the search space?
> > >
> > > Example, suppose we're doing some vision processing and by 
whatever
> > means
> > > we arrive at a good solution.  Then we analyze the solution 
and we
> > discover
> > > that, although it contains 1000 neurones, they are actually 10
> > copies(*) of
> > > the same 90-neurone structure (say an edge-detector) and a 
control
> > network
> > > linking them together(**).  That's not really anything like as
> > large a
> > > solution-space as it looked before the analysis, for two 
reasons:
> > >
> > > (* or 10 "iso-neural" networks, e.g. not copies but 
functionally
> > > equivalent....)
> > >
> > > (** current systems are unlikely to produce this, see below)
> > >
> > > 1) The 10 copies of the edge detector are 10 copies of the 
same set
> > of
> > > dimensions, and thus a sub-space with 10-fold less dimensions 
than
> > it
> > > originally appeared
> > >
> > > 2) The edge-detector and the control network are (arguably) 
not in
> > the same
> > > search-space -- they are "orthogonal".  e.g. the modularity of 
the
> > problem
> > > only requires them to respect the same "interface" 
connections, if
> > does not
> > > required the edge-detector internal works to be finely tuned to
> > match the
> > > control network.  Or, to put it another way, any functional 
edge
> > detector
> > > would work with any functional control network.
> > >
> > > Stronger examples of modularity producing orthogonality can 
easily
> > be
> > > dreamed up.  Consider the case of N sub-nets, each evolved to
> > recognize a
> > > different input class, and a control net which just checks for
> > which
> > > sub-net is reporting the highest confidence.  There is no
> > dependency(***)
> > > between the sub-nets.  (Their internal dependencies are (i) 
report
> > their
> > > confidence on a connection to the control net, (ii) the input 
data
> > format.)
> > >
> > > (*** dependency is the opposite of orthogonality)
> > >
> > > However, one cannot expect a homogeneous evolution procedure to
> > just
> > > happen to produce orthogonal modules.  You need a modular 
evolution
> > system:
> > >
> > > (slowest) mutate modularity
> > > (medium) try topologies within each module
> > > (fastest) play with the weights in each module
> > >
> > > - as people have begun to tinker with.
> > >
> > > Ian Badcoe
> > >
> > >
> > >

> > > http://livingathome.sourceforge.net/
